Halogenated porous melamine polymers were demonstrated to be efficient catalysts for CO2-epoxide cycloaddition, selectively (>99%) producing C3-C12 cyclic carbonates in excellent yields (upto 99%) under solvent and co-catalyst free conditions. The halogenated polymers outperformed benchmark catalysts incorporating only basic (N-doped carbon, ZIF-8, N-rich melamine polymer) or nucleophilic (TBAB, KI) sites. The superior catalytic performance of these inexpensive polymers was attributed to their unique surface chemistry incorporating abundant, stable basic N sites (amine N and protonated N) and nucleophilic (Cl-, Br- or I-) that enabled simultaneous activation of both epoxide and CO2 molecule (supported by kinetic and DFT studies). Further, among halogenated polymers a Br- containing material (PMFBr) presented highest activity owing to its balanced CO2-philicity and strong nucleophilicity. Most importantly, PMFBr was robust, reusable and maintained stable performance for continuous production of C3-C4 cyclic carbonate (120 °C, 0.3–0.83 h-1 WHSVepoxide and 15 bar) in a fixed-bed reactor during 60–190 h TOS. For example, using CO2 as a C1 source various high-value products have been synthesized including polycarbonates, urea, carbamates, bicarbonates, cyclic carbonates, formate, methanol, dimethyl ether and so forth [2,3]. Among these, cyclic carbonates are a class of useful products having diverse industrial applications which range from electrolyte (in lithium-ion batteries), aprotic solvents (green substitute to DMF, DMSO), monomer, additives, as intermediates in a wide range of chemical processes and niche applications in cosmetics and membrane manufacturing processes [4–6]. Traditionally, cyclic carbonates have been produced through the phosgene rote, which utilizes hazardous phosgene regents as the C1 source [7]. In this prospective, the substitution of toxic C1 reagents with CO2, which is plentiful, non-toxic and inexpensive is highly attractive [8–10]. Although phosgene rote is still used for the production bulky cyclic carbonates; at present industrially, all short chain C2-C3 cyclic carbonates are produced by the cycloaddition of CO2 with corresponding epoxides in the presence of quaternary ammonium or phosphonium salts (or ionic liquids) such as tetabutylammoniumbromaide (TBAB), tributylphosphoniumbromide or even their supported forms as catalysts ( Scheme 1) [11,12]. However, there are several drawbacks of the existing catalytic approach which include high catalyst cost, low-moderate activity (which necessities the use of high pressure/stoichiometric excess of CO2) and catalyst leaching (Br- loss) which eventually necessitates downstream purification and distillation steps for product recovery. Thus, development of alternative catalysts which are active, robust and inexpensive is of commercial significance, especially in view of the increasing industrial demand of cyclic carbonates in various sectors [13]. Although, the reaction between CO2 and epoxide is highly exothermic (ca. −42.67 kJmol−1 for propylene oxide and CO2 cycloaddition), the CO2 and epoxide coupling does not occur spontaneously which could be attributed to the thermodynamic stability of reacting molecules, especially CO2 (ΔfH° = −393.5 kJmol−1). In fact, the energy barrier for CO2 cycloaddition with terminal epoxides lacking electron withdrawing substituents such as propylene oxide has been estimated to be between 263.59 and 292.88 kJmol−1, consistent with the thermodynamic disfavorability of the reaction [14,15]. To overcome this thermodynamic restriction, CO2 and epoxide are often activated with molecules such as amines, hydrogen or nucleophile (usually in the form of catalyst) resulting in an overall negative Gibbs free energy, thus making the process thermodynamically viable [16]. In other words, when considering catalyst design, it is essential that the developed catalyst has suitable sites such as nucleophilic, weakly basic (e.g. amine) and/or electrophilic sites to activate the reactants involved in reaction (i.e. epoxide and/or CO2, but preferably both) (Scheme 1) [14–16]. Literature shows that for CO2-epoxide cycloaddition reactions numerous catalysts have been developed/proposed which include metal complexes, metal oxides, metal organic frameworks (MOFs), onium salts, ionic liquids, and Schiff bases [17–22]. However, a careful examination of literature data shows that a vast majority of papers describe catalysts which function only in the presence of strong nucleophilic activators (e.g. KI, TBAB), which highlights the inability of these materials to activate epoxide molecule. In other words, majority of the materials/catalytic systems reported in prior art cannot regard as true catalysts considering the importance of epoxide activation in the overall reaction, such catalysts at best only aid in activation/adsorption of CO2 while epoxide activation takes place over the strong nucleophilic activators (used as co-catalysts) [11–22]. Although, amine bases (supported and unsupported) have been shown to catalyze CO2-epoxide cycloaddition in the absence of strong nucleophilic activators but their performance (activity and selectivity) is considerably inferior to the benchmark nucleophilic catalysts (quaternary ammonium/ phosphonium salts) (the poor activity is attributed mainly to the weak nucleophilicity of amines). In fact, experimentally the apparent activation energy of CO2-propylene oxide reaction has been shown to be ∼2.6 fold higher over amine type catalysts in comparison to strong nucleophilic catalyst i.e. 80.4 kJmol−1 (base catalyst) vs. 30.8 kJmol−1 (nucleophilic catalysts) [23–26]. In recent years numerous bifunctional/multicomponent catalysts (capable of simultaneously activating both epoxide and CO2) have also been developed and studied for CO2 cycloaddition (Scheme 1) [27–29]. For example, Ma et al. reported metal-free porous organic materials as bifunctional catalyst, where the carboxylic acid group (-COOH) works as a Bronsted acidic site, and Br- anion from an ionic liquid functioned as the nucleophilic site, affording upto 90% epoxide conversion at 1 bar CO2 at 40 °C in 48 h [27]. In another work, Yi et et al. reported the use of porous poly-ionic liquid with basic/acidic moieties (-COOH, -NH2), active cations (quaternary ammonium, imidazolium) and nucleophilic ions (Br-, Cl-, OH-) as heterogeneous catalysts for the synthesis of cyclic carbonates from epoxides and CO2 [28]. Wu et al. reported the use of imidazolium-halide ion (polymeric ionic liquid) mesoporous polymer (3-IPMPs-EtI) upon CO2 fixation with epoxides at 10 bar CO2 and 90 °C. It was found that the halide ion improved carbonate conversion (90%) under mild conditions [29]. Similarly, Wang et al. reported urea-functionalized imidazolium-based ionic polymer as an active catalyst for the conversion of propylene oxide to propylene carbonate (99%). The high activity was attributed to the dual sites that are present in this single catalytic system where the urea imidazolium backbone activated CO2 and Br- activated epoxide [30]. Recently, various hyper-cross-linked ionic polymers incorporating N and ionic/halide sites (such as Cl-, Br-) have also been investigated as multifunctional catalyst for CO2-epoxide reactions [31]. In another work, Werner et al. disclosed a polystyrene immobilized bifunctional phosphonium salts (ionic liquids) as alternative catalysts for cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxide. However, the drawbacks of the work are complicated catalyst synthesis, and Br- leaching which results in significant loss of catalyst activity upon reuse [32]. Recently, inexpensive Amberlite resins containing iodide, bromide or chloride anions have also been proposed as effective catalysts for the same reaction. However, a considerable drawback of these resin-based catalyst was their moderate-low activity and poor recyclability (requiring intermediate regeneration) [33]. To summarize, most of the bifunctional catalysts reported till date for CO2-epoxide reactions have major disadvantages including complicated-multistep synthetic procedures, high cost (difficult to scale-up) and/or moderate-poor recyclability. In addition, due to difficulties in catalyst scale-up the stability such catalysts are yet to be validate under intensified conditions (such as those used in continuous flow reactors) [27–33]. It should also be emphasized, in many of the studies reported in literature, CO2-epoxide cycloaddition has been typically studied with highly reactive epoxides possessing strong electrophilic centers as a model substrate (e.g. epichlorohydrin, styrene oxide possessing electron withdrawing substituents), which make is difficult to fairly benchmark the performance of such catalysts for industrial applications involving use of non-activated short chain epoxides (e.g. ethylene, propylene epoxide) as substrates [17–26]. Taking into consideration the above points, we have undertaken the current study with the aim of developing a robust, active, inexpensive and scalable bifunctional catalyst for CO2-epoxide cycloaddition reactions. Considering our previous experience with various N-rich materials such as N-doped carbon and porous N-rich melamine polymers, and particularly the unique CO2 philicity, porosity and lack of acidity in melamine formaldehyde polymers coupled with their high thermal stability. Herein we have selected these porous melamine polymers are as the foundation for the development of improved bifunctional catalyst for CO2-epoxide cycloaddition reactions (Scheme 1) [24,34–36]. More specifically, we intend to enhance the activity of such materials by incorporating additional, highly robust nucleophilic/ionic sites such as Cl-, Br- and I- on their surface through synthetic modifications (to enable simultaneous epoxide and CO2 activation) [34,36]. Moreover, considering the commercial significance of short chain terminal cyclic carbonates (e.g. propylene and butylene carbonate) we also validated the stability of the thus developed catalysts under intensified conditions in a fixed-bed reactor using corresponding short chain epoxides as substrate. Kinetic, mechanistic and DFT (computational studies) are also undertaken to rationalize the improved performance upon halide introduction and validate the bifunctional nature of the developed materials by benchmarking against a non-halogenated counterpart. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Chemicals Melamine (99% Alfa Aesar), paraformaldehyde (97% Alfa Aesar), sodium hydroxide (≥96%, Qualikems), epichlorohydrin (≥99% SRL), 1,2-butylene oxide (99% TCI), 1,2-propylene oxide (99% Aldrich), styrene oxide (>98.0% TCI), 1,2-epoxyoctane (>96.0% Aldrich), 1,2-epoxydodecane (>90% Aldrich), 1,2-epoxy-9-decene (>96% Aldrich), tetrabutylammonium bromide (TBAB) (98.0%, SRL), potassium iodide (99%, Loba Chem), potassium bromide (99%, SRL), formic acid (98% SRL), hydrochloric acid (finar, 37% SRL), hydrobromic acid (48–49%, SRL), hydriodic acid (57%, Sigma), methanol (99.8% SRL), isopropyl alcohol (96%, Finar), and acetone (99.5%, SRL) were procured from commercial sources as used without further purification. High purity CO2 (99.99%) and N2 (99.99%) were procured locally and used without further purification. 2.2 Preparation of catalytic materials The halogenated and non-halogenated porous melamine-formaldehyde polymers were prepared without templates or organic solvents using a modification of sol-gel/hydrothermal polymerization technique reported in our earlier works ( Scheme 2) [24,34,36]. In a typical synthesis, 3.6 g of paraformaldehyde (0.36 mol) and 5.03 g of melamine (0.12 mol) were mixed with 13.6 ml of NaOH (0.125 M) and stirred at 60 °C for 20 minutes to obtain a transparent monomer (hexamethylolmelamine) solution. In the next step an aqueous solution (16 ml) comprising an acid selected from HCOOH (64 mmol), HCl (30 mmol), HBr (24 mmol), or HI (20 mmol) was added as a catalyst to above monomer solution (pH∼5) and the contents stirred at 40 °C under until gelation in a Teflon®-vessel. Finally, the obtained gel was hydrothermally aged at 120 °C for a duration of 4 h. In order to obtain the polymeric catalysts, the autoclave was cooled to room temperature, the contents were collected by filtration, washed with deionized water (until free from halogens, AgNO3 test) and dried in a vacuum oven at 100 °C for 24 h and crushed into a fine powder (the materials were denoted PMFH, PMFCl, PMFBr, and PFHI, respectively, where the suffixs denote acid catalyst used H=HCOOH, Cl=HCl, Br=HBr and I=HI in polymerization step). For benchmarking experiments, KI and KBr activated PMFH (denoted PMFH-KBr and PMFH-KI) were obtained by co-addition of KI or KBr (melamine:KI/KBr ratio was ∼1) during hydrothermal treatment (the final material was subjected to the same treatment as above prior to use). ZIF-8 and N-doped carbon were are synthesized according to standard procedures reported in literature (detailed synthetic procedure are given in supporting information). 2.3 Catalytic material characterization The synthesized catalytic materials were extensively characterized by Fourier-transform Infrared Spectroscopy (FT-IR), Organic Elemental Analysis (CHNS), Powder X-ray Diffraction (XRD), Scanning Electron Microscopy with Energy Dispersive X-ray Spectroscopy (SEM/EDX), X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS), Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM) Thermogravimetric Analysis (TGA) and 13C MAS NMR to evaluate their structural, compositional, morphological and thermal properties. The polymeric supports and catalytic materials were also extensively characterized by N2 physisorption and chemisorption techniques to evaluate their surface-textural, acid-base properties. The specific details of characterization techniques are provided in supporting information. 2.4 Catalytic reaction procedures The direct carbonation of epoxides with CO2 was performed under batch as well as continuous flow conditions. The batch experiments were performed in a custom-made mini autoclave (∼13 ml) under magnetic stirring as described in our earlier works [34,36]. In a typical experiment, the autoclave was charged with desired amount of catalyst (50–300 mg, particle size ≤100 µm), epoxide (9–49 mmol), flushed up to three times with pure CO2 and pressurized to the desired reaction pressure (5–40 bar) to maintain a CO2: epoxide mole ratio of 1–3. The reaction was initiated by heating the autoclave to the desired reaction temperature (80–150 °C) under magnetic stirring (1000 rpm). Experiments under continuous flow were performed in a custom made up-flow vertical fixed-bed reactor allowing concurrent flow of gaseous (CO2) and liquid feed (epoxide) ( Scheme 3). In a typical experiment, 3 g dry catalyst powder (≤100 µm) was packed in SS316 tube (1/2-inch OD, 10 mm ID and length 15 cm) supported on each end by two 2 µm SS316 frits. Next, the reactor was pressurized with CO2 or 1:1 CO2-N2 mixture to 8–15 bar, and the reactor pre-heated to the desired reaction temperature of 100–150 °C, while maintaining a constant flow of CO2 (15–25 ml/min). To initiate the reaction, an undiluted liquid feed (C3-C4 epoxide) was fed using a precision high-pressure syringe pump (New Era pump systems, NE-8000), into the reactor inlet at a weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) of 0.3–0.85 h−1. The system pressure was controlled using a precision back pressure regulator (Equilibar UL3 series). Finally, the product stream, consisting of cyclic carbonate, unreacted epoxide, and CO2, was collected in a gas-liquid separator connected downstream to the reactor. Product quantification was based on liquid 1H NMR and GC-FID techniques [24,35]. The conversion/yield reported were average of two experiments. To determine the fate of the catalyst, the spent catalyst was washed with methanol, dried in a vacuum oven and subjected to various characterizations described in Section 2.3 and supporting information. 2.5 Computational methodology The geometry optimization of all the species was performed using Hybrid Becke functional (B3) for electron exchange and the correlation functional of Lee, Yang and Parr (LYP) using Gaussian 09 software. The details of the computational techniques are provided in supporting information. 3 Result and discussion 3.1 Characterization of melamine based polymeric catalysts The textural and surface properties of the various melamine-based polymers (PMFH, PMFCl, PMFBr, and PFHI) synthesized by the sol-gel/hydrothermal polymerization (Scheme 2) techniques are summarized in Table 1. The data clearly shows the strong impact of acid catalyst used (during gelation step) upon the textural and surface properties of obtained polymers. While, benchmark PMFH material obtained with a weak acid catalyst HCOOH (pKa 3.745) presented a highly porous structure with a large specific surface area (712 m2g−1), PMFI obtained with the strongest Brønsted halo acid catalyst HI (pKa −9.3) and presented the lowest porosity with a low specific surface area of 21 m2g−1, whereas PMFBr and PMFCl obtained with HBr and HCl as catalyst, exhibited surface areas of 78 and 34 m2g−1, respectively (Table 1). The observed difference in textural properties are most likely a consequence of the increased rate of condensation-polymerization over strongly acidic halo acid catalysts, as also evident from the TGA patterns (see below) [24,34,36]. Comparison of the powder XRD and FT-IR analysis revealed the characteristic broad diffraction peak centered around 2Ɵ = 17–30°, and CN (1544 cm−1) and CC (1462 cm−1) stretching vibrations in all polymers, which was similar to the previously reported melamine-formaldehyde derived polymeric materials ( Fig. 1(a-b)) [24,34,36]. Similar to textural properties, in terms of CO2 adsorption capacities (CO2 philicity), considerable variation could also be observed among the synthesized melamine polymers which highlighted the influence of acid catalyst used (during synthesis step) upon material surface textural properties (Table 1). Use of stronger halo acid as catalyst (HI, HBr and HCl) produced more cross-linked polymers with low porosity and lower amount of N functional sites, which translated to lower CO2 physisorption and chemisorption capacities, when compared to the benchmark PMFH material obtained with weakly acidic HCOOH as catalyst (Fig. 1(c-d), Table 1 and Fig. S1 , supporting information). It is also worth noting that neither halogenated nor non-halogenated polymers were able to absorb NH3 in agreement with our previous reports depicting the complete absence of acidic functional groups in such materials [34]. EDX and XPS studies on polymers revealed that with the exception of PMFH, all other materials contained considerable amount of halide (0.61–1.15 mmolg−1) on the surface, establising successful incorporation of halides onto the polymer surface and confirming the dual role of halo acids as both catalyst and halide source during polymerization (Tables 1, 2 and Table S1-S3 , supporting information). Further, in all synthesized materials (including PMFH) the N1s region was deconvoluted into protonated N (400.3 eV), amine N (399.6 eV), and triazine N (398.5 eV), respectively, similar to the melamine-formaldehyde polymers reported in our previous works (Table 2, Fig. 2(b), Figs. S2–S3, supporting information) [34,36]. Similarly, the characteristic high-resolution spectra of the halide regions (Br3d, Fig. 2(d) and Cl2p, Fig. S2, supporting information) provide valuable insights into the corresponding chemical bonding and composition. Both spectra exhibit strong peaks corresponding to halide anions (at ∼68 eV for Br3d and 199 eV for Cl2p), confirming the existence of Br- and Cl- species on the surface of respective halogenated polymers PMFBr and PMFCl [37]. It is likely that these halide anions have been stabilized by the protonated N (cationic) sites present on polymers, as benchmark materials containing KBr and KI on PMFH deactivated rapidly during catalytic use (see below) [24,34,36]. Another important implication supporting the stabilization of halide ions on N is from EDX elemental mapping images depicting uniform, homogeneous and overlapping distribution of N, C, O and halide (Cl, Br, I) elements, respectively, on the polymer surface (Figs. S4–S8, supporting information). It should also be highlighted that despite the lack of porosity, these halide-ion containing melamine polymers exhibited high CO2 philicity, particularly PMFBr presenting CO2 physisorption (uptake) capacity of 1.29 mmolg−1 (highest among halogenated polymers) was ca. 73% of the benchmark halogen free PMFH material. These findings clearly, established the important contribution of N doping and functional N sites towards enhancing the CO2 adsorption capacity (Table 1 , Fig. 1(c-d) and Fig. S1, supporting information). In fact, the CO2 adsorption capacity of some of the developed polymers (viz. PMFH and PMFBr), at room temperature, were en par with various MOF/COF type materials reported in literature [38,39]. The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) patterns of the halogenated polymers, as shown in Fig. 1(e), demonstrated the excellent thermal stability of the halogenated polymers, which was comparable to that of the pristine melamine polymer (PMFH) with two major weight loss events: the 1st one near 100 °C corresponding to removal of adsorbed gases and moisture and 2nd one in the range of 300–450 °C, corresponding to thermal polymerization of the triazine network [24,34,36]. It is also worth highlighting that the presence of halide ions caused a shift in the 2nd major weight loss event towards a lower temperature range of 300–360 °C, when compared to the benchmark PMFH material which exhibited this event at 400–450 °C. This observation suggests the possible catalytic role of halide ions in initiating the thermal polymerization of melamine materials to carbon nitrides. These findings may have important implications in terms of development of new carbon nitride materials that may exhibit different physiochemical properties. Additionally, the 13C MAS NMR analysis indicated the presence of the characteristic triazine ring peak at 166 ppm along with a double resonance at 54 and 48 ppm and 64–82 ppm, respectively, attributed to the CH2 group and ether type bridges linking two melamine moieties together (Fig. 1(f), representative spectra shown for PMFBr) similar to the materials reported in our previous works [24,36]. The FE-SEM and TEM images (shown for a representative halogenated polymer PMFBr) display a textured morphology with disorganized mesoporous structure consistent with the findings of N2 physisorption and similar to the materials reported in our earlier works ( Fig. 3(a-b)) [24,34,36]. Overall, our findings are indicative of the formation of highly cross-linked halogenated mesoporous melamine aldehyde resins with different surface, textural, CO2 basicity, CO2 philicity and structural properties, which may have potential applications in fields such as polymer chemistry, materials science, catalysis and adsorption [24,34,36,40,41]. 3.2 Catalytic performance 3.2.1 Initial benchmarking in batch Considering the unique bifunctional nature of the materials exhibiting both surface nucleophilic and weakly basic N sites, the synthesized halide ion rich melamine formaldehyde polymers were explored as potential catalyst for direct carbonation of terminal non-activating epoxides (i.e. epoxides lacking electron withdrawing substituents e.g. propylene oxide, butylene oxide) with CO2 under solvent, co-catalyst/promoter (e.g. tetraallyl ammonium bromide, KI) free conditions. Initial benchmarking of the bifunctional halogenated polymers were conducted in a batch reactor against well-known mono-functional catalysts such a TBAB, KI, N-doped carbon, ZIF-8 and PMFH using propylene oxide (PO) as a model substrate at 120 °C. It should be highlighted that opposed to literature studies reporting catalyst performance in large inefficient batch reactors and at low pressures where ca. 98–99% of the reactor volume remains unutilized, herein we opted to use more efficient micro batch reactors at 20–30% occupancy (liquid reactant + catalyst) maintaining a CO2:PO mole ratio of close to 1 [28,31]. The results summarized in Table 3 clearly illustrate that among the three groups of materials tested viz. weakly basic, strongly nucleophilic and bifunctional, the porous catalysts incorporating only weakly basic N sites (N-doped carbon, ZIF-8, PMFH) presented lowest activity affording negligible PO conversion (0–7%), while the strongly nucleophilic catalysts (TBAB, KBr and KI) afforded moderate activity with epoxide conversion reaching a maximum of 66% with a quaternary ammonium bromide (TBAB). In contrast, the halogenated melamine polymers (PMFBr, PMFCl and PMFI) afforded improved catalytic activity with PO conversions reaching upto 99% despite the lack of porosity. In fact, for the most active halogenated catalyst (PMFBr), PO conversion easily reached up to ∼79% even with a low catalyst dosage of 3.5 wt% (50 mg), which was almost ∼1.2 fold higher than most active nucleophilic catalyst (TBAB). Among the polymer-based catalysts, the activity order in terms of PO conversion was PMFH<PMFH-KBr<PMFCl<PMFI<<PMFH-KI<PMFH-KI(physical mixture)<PMFBr which is in agreement with the combined effects of CO2 philicity and nucleophlicity (Table 1 and Table 3). The improved activity of KI/KBr activated PMFH and physical mixture of non-halogenated polymer PHFH with nucleophilic promoters in comparison to PMFH signified the importance of nucleophilic epoxide activation in the overall reaction [19–22,38,39]. These findings i.e. activity trend: bifunctional halogenated polymer>strong nucleophilic catalyst>weak N basic catalyst, clearly highlight the importance role of nucleophilic sites (or activators) over porosity and basicity for promoting the CO2-epoxide cycloaddition reactions. The difference in activity, among the halogenated polymers could be most likely related to the differences in nucleophilicity, CO2 philicity, CO2 basicity and textural properties of these materials which influenced their ability to activate epoxides and the CO2 molecule. It is also worth noting that, at 140 °C, the N containing (i.e. weak amine type basic) materials (especially PMFH) could afford significantly improved PO conversions (2–82%), which could be attributed to the ability of such materials to promote epoxide ring opening under harsh conditions (attributed to the weak nucleophilicity of amine N sites). However, under such conditions, considerable amounts of undesirable diols were also co-produced as by-products (7–12%), which renders such materials less attractive as catalysts for the aforementioned transformations (in contrast, diol formation was insignificant over the bifunctional and strongly nucleophilic catalysts, Fig. S9 , supporting information). These preliminary results also highlight the importance of synergy between strong nucleophilic sites and weakly N basic sites present in the halogenated polymers and promoting simultaneousness activation of both reagents (epoxide and CO2) during carbonation of epoxides that results in improved catalyst performance (improvement in conversion rate and cyclic carbonate selectivity). Our results also highlight the importance of epoxide activation (ring opening) in overall reaction kinetics (see below), and the advantage of low temperature epoxide-CO2 carbonation (in terms of desired product selectivity/quality). To further evaluate the influence of CO2 pressure on the catalyst performance, additional experiments were performed at different initial CO2 pressures while keeping the CO2:propylene oxide (PO) mole ratio constant, as well as at different initial CO2:PO mole ratio but keeping the CO2 pressure constant. The results presented in Fig. 4(a) and (b), show that, in both cases, equilibrium PO conversion remained unaffected and reached a value close to the CO2:PO stoichiometry. Also these findings were clearly indicative of the requirement of reagent stoichiometry (CO2:propylene oxide mole ratio), as opposed to CO2 pressure for achieving the desired catalyst performance (i.e. high yield of propylene carbonate), indicating the suitability of PMFBr even for low pressure operations. Furthermore, we also evaluated the carbonation of butylene (BO) and styrene oxide (SO) using the three halogenated polymers (PMFBr, PMFCl and PMFI), which revealed a trend similar to the one observed for PO (Fig. S10, supporting information), consistent with synergistic effects of CO2 philicity, nucleophilicity and leaving ability of halide upon performance of catalyst (Table 1 , Fig. 1 and Fig. S8, supporting information). Considering the observed trends and the demonstrated high catalytic activity, the efficacy of brominated polymer catalyst (PMFBr) was further investigated with various terminal epoxides (C3-C12) and the results are summarized in Fig. 4(c). Among the epoxides evaluated, epichlorohydrin presented the highest reactivity, followed by propylene, butylene and styrene epoxide, while the long chain terminal epoxides were least reactive and required harsher conditions (elevated temperature and large excess of CO2) to afford high yields of the desired products. The observed trend was consistent with the combined steric and electronic effect of substituents as also observed in many studies reported in literature [17–24,35]. Moreover, the PMFBr catalyst was also successfully recycled in the CO2 cycloaddition reaction with PO without any significant loss in its original activity which confirms the excellent operational stability of halogenated polymeric catalysts under reaction/process conditions, in contrast for PMFH-KI (KI activated PMFH), activity dropped with 26% in the 3rd cycle (Table 3). 3.2.2 Batch kinetics (PMFBr vs PMFH) In view of the excellent catalytic efficiency observed for the halogenated polymer, additional kinetic experiments were also conducted to further benchmark the performance of most active halogenated catalyst (PMFBr) against the non-halogenated counterpart (PMFH) using PO as the model substrate (all kinetic experiments were conducted with CO2:PO ratio of 1 using a low catalyst dosage of 50 mg). The kinetic data summarized in Table 4 illustrate that PMFBr presented ca. 54-fold higher activity than the benchmark non-halogenated, mono-functional catalyst PMFH (incorporating only basic sites), at 100 °C, which was consistent with the ability of the former to simultaneously activate both epoxide and CO2 molecule. In fact, PMFBr could catalyze the CO2-epoxide cycloaddition reaction at temperatures as low as 25 °C, while PMFH failed to produce cycloaddition products at temperatures lower than 100 °C, even after extending reaction time up to 48 h. Although, the benchmark non-halogenated material (PMFH) could afford improved activity at elevated temperatures (140–150 °C), PO conversion reached a maximum of 59% only at 24 h and 150 °C. Moreover, in the presence of PMFH as a catalyst, considerable amount of 1,2-propylene glycol (selectivity 3–13%, Table 3) was also produced as a by-product, which reduced the selectivity towards the desirable cyclic carbonates (95–97%). Further, using the pseudo 1st order rate constants (kini based on initial rates) summarized in Table 4, Arrhenius-like plots of ln(kini) vs 1/T were obtained for both catalysts (Fig. 4(d)) (selection of pseudo-first order kinetics was based on literature reports suggesting change in concentration of CO2 adsorbed on catalysts surface to be insignificant within kinetic regime where initial rates have been measured) [24,35]. Using these plots, the apparent activation energies (Ea) for the CO2-PO cycloaddition reaction were estimated to be 40.34 kJmol−1 and 79.49 kJmol−1 for PMFBr and PMFH, respectively. Clearly, the 2-fold higher apparent activation energy obtained for PMFH in comparison to PMFBr was consistent with the catalytic superiority of the later (bifunctional brominated polymer) over the former (mono-functional polymer), which could be attributed to the unique ability of the Br- containing melamine polymers to activate both epoxide and CO2 molecule during CO2-epoxide cycloaddition reactions. In other words, the reduced activation energy suggests that over PMFBr reaction proceeds via epoxide activation on nucleophilic Br- sites with activated or adsorbed CO2, while over PMFH reaction most likely proceeds though more challenging base catalyzed pathway involving epoxide-CO2 activation on weakly nucleophilic amine type sites [14,15,24,35]. Further, our experimental findings are also supported by computational studies, which show the amine type N catalyzed pathway through epoxide-CO2 activation on weakly nucleophilic amine N-type sites to be more challenging than the bifunctional pathway proceeding through epoxide activation/ring-opening on strongly nucleophilic sites (see below). 3.2.3 Computational studies and plausible mechanism DFT studies were performed to further unravel the intricate mechanisms involved in the synthesis of cyclic carbonate via. the CO2-epoxide (PO as model substrate) reactions using both the halogenated (PMFBr) and non-halogenated (PMFH) melamine formaldehyde polymers. Given the experimentally observed CO2 philicity of developed polymeric catalysts, comparative analyses were performed to examine the polymer's role in activating CO2 and how the activated CO2 promotes a more favorable reaction pathway. The intermediates and transition states were optimized in gas phase using B3LYP/6–31 G(d,p) for C, H, N, and O atoms and the LANL2DZ basis set with ECP was employed for Br atom [14,15]. The DFT optimized structures involved in computations are provided in supporting information (Figs. S11–S12). In case of non-halogenated polymer PMFH (Pathway I), the initial step involves the formation of a van der Waal’s complex (Int-I) among the PMFH catalyst, epoxide, and CO2 through van der Waals interactions ( Fig. 5(a) and Fig. S11(a), supporting information). Subsequently, the nitrogen atom of melamine within the PMFH catalyst combines with the less hindered carbon atom, resulting in the opening of the epoxide ring. Concurrently, the oxo-anion attacks CO2, leading to the formation of the corresponding carbonate (Int-II) via a concerted process through the transition state TS1. In the following step, the oxo-anion of the intermediate carbonate (Int-II) combines with the carbon atom, thereby regenerating the PMFH catalyst and facilitating the formation of cyclic carbonate (Pdt) through the transition state TS2 (Fig. 5(a) and Fig. S11(a), supporting information). To determine the catalyst's role in the CO2 activation and its impact on the reaction process, the reaction pathway was also repeated with activated CO2 (Fig. S11(b), supporting information). The results indicated that when combined with activated CO2 molecule, the activation energy barrier for carbonate formation (TS1) was reduced further by 7.4 kcalmol−1 (30.96 kJmol−1) (Fig. 5(a) and Table S2, supporting information). In case of the halogenated polymer (PMFBr), the reaction proceeded through nucleophilic pathway (pathway II) (Fig. S12(a), supporting information), where the hydrogen atom located on the cationic nitrogen site of melamine in the PMFBr catalyst forms a hydrogen bond with the epoxide (PO) oxygen (Int-I). In the subsequent step, the counter bromoanion of the PMFBr, the catalyst interacts with the unhindered carbon site of the PO, leading to ring opening via TS1. In this concerted step, the bromine atom is inserted into the epoxide ring, while simultaneously, the oxo-anion abstracts a hydrogen atom from the cationic nitrogen site of melamine in the PMFBr catalyst, resulting in the formation of 1-bromopropan-2-ol (Int-II). Next, CO2 combines with 1-bromopropan-2-ol, generating the carbonate intermediate (Int-IV) via TS2 and Int-III. Subsequently, the oxo-anion of the carbonate intermediate participates in the formation of cyclic carbonate and regenerating the PMFBr catalyst (Pdt) via intermediate (Int-V) (Fig. 5(b) and Fig. S12(a), supporting information). Similar to the PMFH catalyst, the role of activated CO2 was also investigated (Fig. S11(a), supporting information). The results indicated that use of activated CO2 further reduced the overall activation energy barrier for the reaction by approximately 2.0 kcalmol−1 (8.368 kJmol−1) consistent with the positive role of catalyst CO2 philicity (CO2 activating ability) in improving the materials catalytic performance (Fig. S12(b), and Table S2, supporting information). To summarize, in both processes (i.e. pathway I and pathway II) involving PMFH and PMFBr catalysts, the energetically favorable reaction pathway was facilitated by activated CO2. Notably, in the CO2 combining step whereupon the oxo-anion of the epoxide attacks activated CO2, the activation energy barrier for the PMFBr catalyst was found to be lowest 18.5 kcalmol−1 (77.40 kJmol−1), most importantly this value was ca ∼2 fold lower than that of PMFH catalyst at 36.2 kcalmol−1 (151.46 kJmol−1) involving activated CO2 (Fig. 5 and Table S2, supporting information). This outcome strongly supports the experimental findings and further validates the proposed bi-functional nature of developed brominated melamine formaldehyde polymer catalyst (PMFBr). Based on the computational results, a plausible mechanism was proposed for CO2-epoxide cycloaddition reactions in the presence of either the non-halogenated (PMFH) or the most active halogenated porous melamine formaldehyde polymer (PMFBr) and presented in Scheme 4. 3.2.4 Catalytic performance under intensified conditions Motivated by the above findings in batch, the performance of most active halogenated polymer catalyst (PMFBr) was further evaluated under industrially relevant continuous flow conditions and benchmarked against both PMFH and PMFH-KI (the KI activated PMFH). All experiments were performed in a lab-scale micro-fixed reactor using propylene/butylene oxide (PO/BO) and gaseous CO2 as substrates (120–150 °C, 12 bar). Table 5, summarizes the main results obtained from continuous experiments with the three different catalyst, which confirm the catalytic superiority of PMFBr and PMFH-KI over the non-halogenated counterpart PMFH. Similar, to the trends observed in batch mode, PMFH afforded low activity with 0% PO conversion upto 130 °C, while at 140 °C and 150 °C the conversion increased to 47% and 90%, respectively, (WHSVPO was 0.3 h−1) consistent with inability of weakly nucleophilic N sites to promote epoxide activation at low temperature. In contrast, over PMFBr and PMFH-KI PO conversion reached 78–83% at 120 °C at 0.83 h−1 and 0.3 h−1 WHSVPO, respectively. The activity trend remained unaffected when using BO oxide as a substrate with conversion reaching 86% at 140 °C and 0.3 h−1 WHSVBO. Overall, the activity trends observed in the fixed-bed reactor was in clear agreement the advantage of bifunctional catalysts upon continuous CO2 cycloaddition with epoxides similar, to the trends observed upon batch mode (Sections 3.2.1–3.2.2). Further, in terms of desired product selectivity both PMFBr and PMFH-KI afforded >99% cyclic carbonate selectivity in a fixed-bed reactor, while in case of PMFH selectivity varied between 90% and 97%, due to the formation of considerable amounts of 1,2-glycols as by-products. The results of long-term stability tests conducted with PMFH, PMFBr and PMFH-KI are shown in Fig. 6. The trends in Fig. 6(a-b), clearly illustrate the excellent operational stability/durability of the brominated polymer catalyst (PMFBr), sustaining stable performance during carbonation of terminal epoxides at 120 and 140 °C. In contrast, the KI activated PMFH catalyst showed rapid loss of activity at 120 °C with a PO conversion dropping from 83% to 30% in 15 h, which clearly highlights the importance of the applied synthetic methodology (and halide precursor used) in obtaining catalysts with stable and active nucleophilic sites (Fig. 6(a-b)). It is also interesting to note that pristine PMFH also presented stable catalytic performance similar to the Br- free materials reported in our earlier works (Fig. S13, supporting information). However, these non-halogenated materials are less desirable as a catalyst as they required the use of very high reaction temperature of 150 °C to afford a performance on par to the halogenated counterpart, PMFBr. Moreover, it also produced a colored product containing considerable amounts (3–10%) of 1,2-glycols (Table 1 , Fig. S9(a), supporting information), which would require additional treatments such as decolorization and distillation prior to end use. In this study, the catalytic performance of PMFBr was also evaluated using diluted CO2 (50% CO2 diluted with N2) as a CO2 source in view of the advantages of utilizing diluted CO2 feeds (e.g. flue gas) in industrial process. As shown in Fig. S14 (supporting information) PMFBr retained its high catalytic efficacy even with diluted CO2, maintaining a stable propylene carbonate production during 100 h time on stream when operating under conditions comparable to those used for pure CO2 (120 °C, 15 bar). Considering the obtained high productivity (6.34–2.25 mmolProductgcath−1), excellent selectivity (>99%) and long-term durability (Table 5 , Fig. 6 and Fig. S14 , supporting information), observed for PMFBr with both purified and diluted CO2, it can be deemed a potential catalyst for further scale up and optimization for large scale the production of propylene carbonate [42]. 3.2.5 Spent catalyst characterization To further corroborate the experimentally observed stability of halogenated melamine catalyst (PMFBr), PMFBr particles recovered from catalyst bed after ∼190 h time on stream were subjected to various physio-chemical characterizations similar to the pristine catalyst. From the data presented in Fig. 7(a), it is evident that the recovered material mainlined 45% of its original porosity and, most importantly, its mesoporous structure, even after prolonged operation. The slight reduction in the specific surface area and pore volume could be attributed to the partial blockage of the polymer surface by adsorbed high boiling products [24,35]. The spent material exhibited the same thermal stability (Tmax) as the fresh/pristine material, as shown in Fig. 7(b). FTIR analysis of the catalyst (Fig. 7(c)) demonstrated that one could not observe any changes in the chemistry of the surface functional group of the polymeric material after being exposed to the catalytic operation and it retained the characteristic CN (1544 cm−1) and CC vibrations of melamine polymers [24,34,36,43]. However, the TGA patterns of 190 h PMFBr exhibited an additional weight loss event between 150 and 300 °C attributed to presence of adsorbed or accumulated high boiling organic products/impurities on its surface. XPS analysis of the spent catalyst particles evidenced no significant change in the composition and surface chemistry of the spent PMFBr material even after prolonged use and, most importantly, the distribution of surface N and Br species remained almost unchanged in good agreement with the observed stability trends (Table 2 and Fig. 7(d-e)). However, we observed considerable increase in carbon (41.51–54.28 at%) and oxygen content (5.5–6.83 at%) on spent PMFBr with proportionate decrease in N (41.5–38.49 at%) and Br content (1.05–0.6 at%), consistent with deposition high boiling organic products/impurities on catalyst surface upon prolonged operation (fouling) as also indicated by TGA and N2 physisorption data [24,35]. The TEM, FE-SEM and EDX elemental mapping images indicated that the pore structure, morphology and element distribution were uniform, similar to those of the pristine PMFBr catalyst (Table 2 , Fig. 7(f) and Fig. S7, supporting information). These findings provide strong evidence in support of robustness of PMFBr catalyst under intensified operational conditions of a fixed-bed reactor, which is critical for any catalyst’s practical application in the large-scale [42]. 3.3 Discussion Herein novel halogenated melamine formaldehyde polymers synthesized via simple hydrothermal approach involving gelation/hydrothermal polymerization of hexamethylolmelamine (melamine-paraformaldehyde derived) in the presence of catalytic amounts of halo acids (e.g. HI, HBr or HCl) have been developed as low-cost bifunctional catalysts for CO2-epoxide reactions (Scheme 2). These materials exhibited a mesoporous structure with high CO2 philicity/CO2 basicity (0.52–1.29 mmolg−1 at 22 °C and 1 bar) and high density of nucleophilic halide ions (0.61–1.15 mmolg−1) comparable to the expensive porous poly-ionic liquid and hyper-crosslinked ionic polymers reported in earlier works [28,31]. Advantageously, the approach reported herein avoids the use of halogenated solvents, toxic quaternization agents and complicated multistep work-up, which has been typically employed in the preparation of similar bifunctional catalysts (e.g. poly-ionic liquids, immobilized bifunctional phosphonium salts, immobilized ionic liquids, hyper-crosslinked ionic polymers), this not only results in substantial minimization of hazardous solvent waste generated but also reduces the overall catalyst production costs [28,31,44]. Further, while many studies in the open literature have typically opted for catalytic performance evaluation in batch (or semi batch type) reactors at low pressure (even 1 bar); a simple approximation using the gas equation shows that for 20 mmol epoxide (1.4 ml for C3 epoxide), nearly 600 ml CO2 would be required at STP, which translates to the requirement of very large, inefficient batch reactors wherein ca. 98% of the reactor would be left unutilized by the liquid reactant (epoxide), which was in fact the case for a study reported by Yi et al. depicting epichlorohydrin cycloaddition with CO2 at 1 bar over bifunctional poly-ionic liquids, while in an another study upon conversion of 5 mmol epoxide (styrene oxide) over a hyper-crosslinked ionic polymer catalyst, a 100 ml batch reactor was required (Table S3, supporting information) [28,44]. Further, a careful evaluation of the experimental details in the literature shows that in vast majority of the studies, adequate description of the reactor has not been included, which makes it difficult to estimate the exact amount of CO2 or CO2:epoxide (ratio) used, and thus obtain a fair benchmarking of catalyst (Table S3, supporting information) [27,29–31]. Thus, in this study, we also evaluated the performance of the developed catalytic materials under varying pressures at fixed (as well as varied) CO2:epoxide stoichiometry, which shows comparable yields at fixed stichometry, irrespective of pressure, thus confirming the importance of CO2:epoxide stoichiometry in achieving the desired yield/catalytic performance and also the high efficacy of the developed catalytic materials [28,31,44]. Most importantly, the Br- ion containing halogenated melamine formaldehyde catalyst developed in the study i.e. PMFBr, outperforms benchmark nucleophilic and basic catalyst and also demonstrates excellent performance in a fixed-bed during extended operation (Fig. 6). This corroborates the industrial usefulness of brominated melamine formaldehyde polymer (PMFBr) catalyst as cost-effective alternatives to benchmark strongly nucleophilic (tetabutylammoniumbromaide, tributylphosphoniumbromide, KI etc., Table 2) as well as similar bifunctional catalysts reported in literature (Table S3, supporting information) for high quality cyclic carbonate production. The unique stability of the developed polymeric catalyst could be attributed to its high N content and, particularly, the presence of large amounts of stable (cationic) pronated N sites (ca. 37–38% of total N) that aided in stabilization of the nucleophilic Br- anions on catalyst surface. Overall, this study provides valuable insights into the design and optimization of cost-effective catalytic systems for the CO2-epoxide carbonation reactions under industrially relevant solvent, co-catalyst free and continuous flow conditions, and highlights the potential of a brominated porous melamine formaldehyde as an alternative catalyst for large scale production of cyclic carbonates. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, novel porous halogenated melamine polymers were synthesized through a modified hydrothermal approach. These halide anion rich polymeric materials demonstrated excellent activity for cyclic carbonate production via CO2-epoxide reactions under solvent and additive-free conditions. The observed performance of the polymeric catalyst was attributed to their unique bifunctional nature incorporating stable, strong nucleophilic (Cl-, Br- and I-) and weakly basic amine type N sites that enabled simultaneous activation of both epoxide and CO2 molecule (even at room temperature). Accordingly, the most active halogenated polymer (PMFBr) incorporating high density of strongly nucleophilic Br- sites (0.61 mmolg−1) and a high CO2 philicity (1.29 mmolg−1 at 22 °C) easily outperformed various benchmark mono-functional strongly nucleophilic catalysts (TBAB/KI/KBr) and weakly basic catalysts (N-doped carbon, ZIF-8 and PMFH). The bifunctional nature of the developed halogenated catalyst (PMFBr) was validated by both experimental kinetic and computational DFT studies which showed a two-fold lower energy barrier for PMFBr in comparison to the benchmark PMFH (non-halogenated counterpart presenting only weakly basic N sites). Most importantly, the developed PMFBr catalyst was robust, reusable and maintained a stable catalytic performance for terminal C3-C4 epoxide (propylene and butylene oxide) conversion in a fixed-bed reactor during 60–190 h time on stream with gaseous/diluted CO2 as a substrate which validates its industrial potential. coredata.dc:description: Halogenated porous melamine polymers were demonstrated to be efficient catalysts for CO2-epoxide cycloaddition, selectively (>99%) producing C3-C12 cyclic carbonates in excellent yields (upto 99%) under solvent and co-catalyst free conditions. The halogenated polymers outperformed benchmark catalysts incorporating only basic (N-doped carbon, ZIF-8, N-rich melamine polymer) or nucleophilic (TBAB, KI) sites. The superior catalytic performance of these inexpensive polymers was attributed to their unique surface chemistry incorporating abundant, stable basic N sites (amine N and protonated N) and nucleophilic (Cl-, Br- or I-) that enabled simultaneous activation of both epoxide and CO2 molecule (supported by kinetic and DFT studies). Further, among halogenated polymers a Br- containing material (PMFBr) presented highest activity owing to its balanced CO2-philicity and strong nucleophilicity. Most importantly, PMFBr was robust, reusable and maintained stable performance for continuous production of C3-C4 cyclic carbonate (120 °C, 0.3–0.83 h-1 WHSVepoxide and 15 bar) in a fixed-bed reactor during 60–190 h TOS.
